physical_examinations.relevant_findings: 40-year-old Caucasian male with a 28-year history of insulin-dependent diabetes, hypertension, peripheral vascular disease, diabetic retinopathy, diabetic nephropathy, and a prior myocardial infarction. C-peptide levels were below the lower limit of detection. The pancreas weight was decreased with an RPW of 0.49. Histological analysis showed a marked loss of b cells, extremely low insulin area (0%) and mass (1.5 mg) with no evidence of b-cell proliferation. Moderate acinar atrophy and acinar and periductular fibrosis were also observed.

45-year-old Hispanic male with a 20-year duration of diabetes initially treated with oral antihyperglycemic agents. He presented with diabetic ketoacidosis and had an elevated HbA1c level of 8.3% and BMI of 25.3 kg/m2. Clinical diagnosis was type 2 diabetes. Pancreas weight and RPW were low, and histological analysis showed small insulin+islets without insulin-negative islets. Insulin mass was markedly reduced.

19-year-old Caucasian female with a 3-year history of insulin-dependent diabetes. The pancreas obtained was severely atrophied and weighed 21.3 g. Histological analysis showed numerous and variably sized islets containing b cells but also severe amyloidosis; moderate to severe islet degeneration was noted.

26-year-old African American female with a 15-year history of insulin-dependent diabetes, with normal C-peptide levels at death. The pancreas weight and RPW were within normal limits. Histological analysis revealed all islets were insulin+ with insulin mass within normal limits but exhibited slightly abnormal architecture.

13-year-old Caucasian male with type 1 diabetes of 5 years’ duration and undetectable C-peptide. The pancreas weight was 29.4 g with a low RPW of 0.51. Insulin+islets were frequent with some showing insulitis and high HLA-ABC expression. Insulin area and mass were low.
12-year-old Caucasian female with type 1 diabetes of 9 years’ duration, undetectable C-peptide, and low insulin mass. Overall, few insulin+islets were observed, indicating significant b-cell loss.
